title: Empathy Applicability Modeling for General Health Queries
summary: This paper introduces the Empathy Applicability Framework (EAF) to enable anticipatory modeling of empathy needs in patient queries, a crucial aspect often lacking in LLM-driven clinical workflows. EAF classifies queries based on clinical, contextual, and linguistic cues, validated by a dual-annotated benchmark dataset that demonstrates strong classifier performance against baselines.

title: Contrastive Geometric Learning Unlocks Unified Structure- and Ligand-Based Drug Design
summary: This paper introduces ConGLUDe, a novel contrastive geometric model that unifies structure-based and ligand-based computational drug design. By integrating protein and ligand representations and implicitly predicting binding sites without predefined pockets, ConGLUDe achieves state-of-the-art performance in virtual screening, target fishing, and ligand-conditioned pocket prediction across diverse benchmarks.

title: Collaborative Multi-Agent Test-Time Reinforcement Learning for Reasoning
summary: Multi-Agent Test-Time Reinforcement Learning (MATTRL) is introduced to address the instability and resource intensiveness of traditional multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) for LLM-driven systems. This framework enhances multi-agent deliberation at inference time by forming specialist teams, integrating retrieved textual experiences, and utilizing credit assignment for robust, accurate decision-making. It demonstrates significant accuracy improvements across medical, math, and education benchmarks.

title: Human-AI Co-design for Clinical Prediction Models
summary: This paper introduces HACHI, an iterative human-in-the-loop framework that utilizes AI agents to accelerate the development of fully interpretable clinical prediction models (CPMs) by exploring concepts in unstructured clinical notes. HACHI significantly outperforms existing approaches, discovers novel clinically relevant concepts, and enhances model generalizability across sites and time for prediction tasks like acute kidney injury and traumatic brain injury. It highlights the critical role of human experts in guiding the AI learning process to build safer and more effective CPMs.

title: POWDR: Pathology-preserving Outpainting with Wavelet Diffusion for 3D MRI
summary: POWDR introduces a novel pathology-preserving outpainting framework for 3D MRI, leveraging a conditioned wavelet diffusion model to address data scarcity and class imbalance in medical imaging. It effectively retains real pathological regions while generating diverse, anatomically plausible surrounding tissue, thereby enhancing machine learning model performance for tasks like tumor segmentation without fabricating lesions.

title: Changes in Visual Attention Patterns for Detection Tasks due to Dependencies on Signal and Background Spatial Frequencies
summary: This paper investigates how visual attention patterns in medical image signal detection tasks are influenced by the spatial frequency properties of both the signal (lesion) and the complex background. Using simulated digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) images, the study found that detection errors primarily stem from decision failures at later perceptual stages, and that visual attention engagement, evidenced by fixation duration, adapts based on the interplay between lesion morphology and anatomical noise.

title: Breaking the Bottlenecks: Scalable Diffusion Models for 3D Molecular Generation
summary: This paper provides a principled reinterpretation of the Directly Denoising Diffusion Model (DDDM) for 3D molecular generation using the Reverse Transition Kernel (RTK) framework, establishing theoretical clarity for its efficient deterministic denoising. This unification addresses key bottlenecks in traditional diffusion models, enabling faster convergence, higher structural fidelity, and enhanced chemical validity in generating novel molecular structures. The framework ensures numerical stability and preserves molecular symmetries, making 3D molecular generation more scalable and reliable.

title: Variance-Penalized MC-Dropout as a Learned Smoothing Prior for Brain Tumour Segmentation
summary: This paper introduces UAMSA-UNet, an Uncertainty-Aware Multi-Scale Attention-based Bayesian U-Net designed for robust brain tumor segmentation. It leverages Monte Carlo Dropout to learn a data-driven smoothing prior and employs a novel variance-penalized loss to produce spatially coherent masks, addressing the noisy boundaries common in existing U-Net approaches. UAMSA-UNet significantly improves segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency on BraTS datasets.

title: Simulations Predict Improved Valve Performance Without Direct Leaflet Intervention After Neonatal Truncus Arteriosus Repair
summary: This study employed computational simulations to investigate the impact of hemodynamic changes following neonatal Truncus Arteriosus (TA) repair on the performance of an associated quadricuspid valve, without direct leaflet intervention. The simulations accurately predicted that altered postoperative hemodynamics significantly improved valve coaptation and eliminated regurgitation, mirroring in-vivo clinical observations.

title: Temporal Fusion Nexus: A task-agnostic multi-modal embedding model for clinical narratives and irregular time series in post-kidney transplant care
summary: Temporal Fusion Nexus (TFN) is a novel multi-modal and task-agnostic embedding model that effectively integrates irregular time series data and unstructured clinical narratives for risk prediction. Applied to a retrospective cohort of 3382 post-kidney transplant patients, TFN achieved superior performance in predicting graft loss, graft rejection, and mortality compared to state-of-the-art models and unimodal baselines. The model's robust performance, enhanced by clinical text integration, along with its interpretable latent factors, underscores its potential for advanced clinical decision support.

title: AUV Trajectory Learning for Underwater Acoustic Energy Transfer and Age Minimization
summary: Internet of underwater things (IoUT) is increasingly gathering attention with the aim of monitoring sea life and deep ocean environment, underwater surveillance as well as maintenance of underwater installments. However, conventional IoUT devices, reliant on battery power, face limitations in lifesp...
